Posts.Title: Nipple Removal

Posts.Content: Suzie,   How much did it cost you?  I'm not o a masectomy (not yet anyways) Just the nipple and areola, the cancer went into the nipple.  The insurance I have doesn't cover reconstruction, it's government and they don't have to abide by government laws.   Thanks for responding  -  Jill
Posts.Title: Nipple Removal

Posts.Content: Just an update on my breast lift questions response, my medical coverage is through Medicare and Medi-Cal in California.  Even though the law is federal it does not apply to these federal and state medical insurance programs.  That's the government for you.   Has anyone any experience with these guys?   Thanks,
Posts.Title: medicare don't pay

Posts.Content: On 8/9/2008 julie8 wrote: I have been taking Arimidex for 11 months - the joint and bone pain is getting worse.  My question for any of you out there who have had joint / bone pain from Arimidex and have stopped taking Arimidex -  has your joint and bone pain improved or has the damage been done and you are still experiencing the same difficulties with the pain as you were when you stopped taking it?  I am trying to stick it out - I am HER/2 positive and really want to take it for the full 5 years,  and will for a while longer  IF when I so stop  the symptoms will reverse.  If they don't reverse I am not sure how much  more I want to take before I switch to something else.  Thanks! Hi Juie 8: I also have taken Armidex for 6 months, not a year, and the joint and bone pain was really bad for a side effect.  I ended up having to take pain medication to counteract it and that did not make alot of sense so my oncologist changed me over to Femara.  I was off of both for a couple of weeks and was improving, however Femara seems to be having the same effect no improvement so I've stopped taking it for over a week and have noticed an improved.  I have other skeletal problems so I can't blame it all on these 2 drugs - just the worsening.  We'll see.  I getting Phys Therapy one for my back and neck and another for my breast.  I'm hoping I can learn to get along with Femara because I don't even want to try Tamoxofin so if this does work I'm done for now.  Ask your DR. taht's why we have them, and lord knows we've paid for it in more ways than one.  Good Luck.
Posts.Title: Arimidex - side effects

Posts.Content: It's Jill again.  Another info source for ARM is "medical/newstoday.com/articles/65444/php".  The Dr. who started the surgery.   Jill
Posts.Title: Lymph Dissection

Posts.Content: Hi all -it's been awhile.  This cancer stuff takes alot of time if you want to know whats going on with your body. I had a Partial and Sentinal Node Dissection (1 node positive).  I am now scheduled for a ALND (all nodes).  Because of the side effects I'm thinking about backing out - if it's going to efffect my quality of life (what I have left) I think I can skip on it.  And no radiation or Chemo.  Does anyone have any info or experience with this? Thanks  -  Happy Holidays  -  Jill
Posts.Title: Lymph Dissection

Posts.Content: Thank you all for the responses and infos... Update:  Met with my surgeon again for another post-op and we further descussed the dissection.  His plan is to use a newer technique I believe called ARM Arm Reverversal Mapping.  Involves injection of blue dye into the arm and not removing the nodes from the axillary.  This has had very positive results.  There is a research paper etc., by Claude Nos, in Paris @ BioTech available online.  I found by searching "Claude Nos" on Google.  Things are looking better. Merry Christmas  -  JillW
Posts.Title: Lymph Dissection

Posts.Content: On 12/29/2008 Leemg wrote: I had an old fashion lymph node dissection rather than sentinel 5 years ago, 11 nodes total (all negative TG) and I recovered from surgery very well, did my arm exercises, can hardly notice any scar and no after effects at all.  I also had 30+ lymph nodes removed from the opposite axillary area over 30 years ago for melanoma surgery, and I had about 9 lymph nodes removed from my left neck and thyoid area for thyroid cancer.  Of course, they tell me, which I didn't know for about 30 years, that they should not use a blood pressure cup, needles etc. from the arm with lymph node removal.  For me, that is both sides.  I've been told by an ER doctor that they should only be using my legs for this because of lymphedema developing which can occur at any time.  Thus far I have not had a problem with this either.  I wouldn't be overly concerned about having addditional nodes removed.  I wouldn't be overly concerned accept for the fact I had major pain that Perecet could not even touch.  And I think about that pain times thirty.  Which means hosipitalizited with MS.  I know they want chemo and that is just an added pain and discomfort.   I really need to do some sole searching and on this one with myself and my children.  I'm just turning 50 but am already tired of life. Thanks, Jill

Posts.Title: Prosthesis Lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Lump & lymphectomy 1 1/2 yrs ago, radiation 1 year ago for stage 1 CA. Breast became lymphedemic 2 wks after sugery and never went down.  Just beginning Phys Therapy for fluid drainage and it has been very helpfull and I feel hopeful I'll finally have a smaller breast and reduced pain soon.  I've been tanning indoors and this seems to have helped alot.  I know there is alot of controversy over indoor tanning and am wondering if anyone out there has factual or personal experience to share about this.   Thank you,
Posts.Title: Tanning

Posts.Content: On 9/22/2008 Leemg wrote: It is not unusual for BC to show up in the opposite breast.  At the time of diagnosis in one breast the new protocol is to have an MRI of the opposite breast before surgery to insure it is not present in that breast as well.  Many doctors have not been doing that but research has shown it is a good protocol.  There are also tumor markers present as in my case which are indicative of a recurrence in either breast.  If it is still confined just to the opposite breast, it is still considered a local occurence and is curable with the proper treatment.  If there has to be a recurrence that is what you would opt to happen.  Once it becomes distant they no longer speak of cure.  Also, recent recommendations for woman who have dense breasts, high risk, (of course, we are) and those of us who have reconstruction with implants should have MRI's.  Yes, they are more inclined to pick up false positives.  That was the situation in my case but like someone else wrote, I would rather go through a few days of uncertainty they have it spread beyond the breast.  Best of luck to you! Thanks for the info.,  and you think you learned most of it the first time round.  I had two tumors.  Picked up a lucky penny today and the path report said one was benign!  The other grade I-II, infiltrating ductal CA.  I hate learning about all this new info after the fact, but at least I hope I'm better armed this time round.  Thanks again  -  Jill
Posts.Title: Opposite breast cancer

Posts.Content: I've just been dx with cancer in my opposite breast with two tumors this time around.  Just happend not allot of info.  Just should up on a random mammogram.  My first invegest work on the net I've found that everyone should have an MRI on the oppsite breast because of the high reoccurence rate.  Any one have more info or whereabouts for good facts?  Thanks. Jill
Posts.Title: Opposite breast cancer

Posts.Content: On 9/20/2008 shaanjh wrote: Hi Jill, Breast Cancer is giving more pain than normal. and the MRI is also good idea . but Breast Cancer doesn't reoccurring Breast Cancer MRI is showing same and there are no reliable instructor than doctors. so go to the doctor he/she will help you. ------------------------- Breast Cancer - http://www.bodyhealthdebate.co.uk " If you can't accept losing, you can't win."     It's a little late for me and MRI's info was meant for those out there not dx with it yet.  However MRI's show a lot of false positives and needless biopies.  I'd rather have a needless biopsy than cancer at a later stage.  Thanks for your input. jill
Posts.Title: Opposite breast cancer

Posts.Content: On 9/20/2008 trehouse60 wrote: Hi Jill, Sorry that you're back in the club. Breast cancer does frequently recur in the opposite breast, and yes MRI of that breast is a good idea if there is some indication of recurrence.  But the cancer doesn't always recur in the breast.  Mine skipped straight to my lungs - mammogram was showing me to be cancer free, and MRI of breast would have shown the same thing, cause it just wasn't there in the breast any more.  There are no reliable predictors of where or when it might recur - at least none that I know of, or none that were made available to me. I'm not sure if this answers your question or not.  At any rate, my heart goes out to you that you are fighting this all over again. Sincerely, Tre It's my second time around however I am much more educated and prepared for the battle.  And that "battle" is meant for the doctors who want to dimiss your complaints and ideas.  In the mean time I feel my body is simply a time bomb waiting to go off.  And I'm okay with that.   Thanks  -  Jill
Posts.Title: Opposite breast cancer

Posts.Content: On 2/11/2008 KATHY IN CALIFORNIA wrote: After a lumpectomy of a "non-agressive" type breast tumor (mucinous) and six weeks of radiation (completed 11 months ago)I've been doing pretty well.  About 6 weeks ago I noticed some changes in my breast.  Change in nipple color, (loss of pigment)  and a thickening of tissue. I've been in for an ultrasound and there didn't seem to be anything amiss.  Since then, more changes,( redness and swelling around it) that Doc says might be the result of the radiation but I should have another mammogram.  I'm trying to minimalize the tests/Dr.appts since I don't have insurance.  Anyone have a similar experience?  I've also been on aromasin for 10 months now too.  I could sure use some feed back. Thanks, worry wort? I've been having similar sypmtoms that they, oncologists aren't explaining.  I now have aligator skin like leather on half my breat and is numb.  Now sudden pain underneath the breast and going down a vein.  Who knos?  I might get an utra sound and see the Dr. Nurse tomorrow.  We shall see. It's been 11 months since my surgery and about 6 months since radiation tx.

It's been 11 months since my surgery and about 6 months since radiation tx.You are living in California?  And no insurance.  Call Dept. of Health Care Services BCCTP Program.  Breast and Cervical Cancer Tx Program.  They provide cover for breast cancer pts for 18months.  1 (800) 824 0088. There is help out there! Good 'Luck'

Posts.Content: Hi, I had radiation treatment in Jun/July '07.  My skin on my lower breast is turning into a leather type bumpy with numbness.  Has anyone experienced this.  I can't find any info on this.  Thank you,   Jill
Posts.Title: radiation skin changes

Posts.Content: This is a continuation/follow up on the alligator hard tissue issue  Last week I started having pain underneath the effected breast. Had an ultrasound that questioned the tissue which the radiologist said was okay.  Yeah right.  Then X-Rays which showed 2 fractured ribs which was caused by coughing!  The radiation has caused deformities, enlargement, discoloration, shrunk the pectoral muscles and apparently weakened the bones below the area radiated.  I'm on vacation for a month but plan to get aggresive with all the medical people involved with my treatment both present and past.  If I had to do it over again I would opt not to have the radiation treatment.  It is becoming apparent that these side effects are permanent.  Beware of the information they don't give you before treatments.
Posts.Title: radiation tissue damage

Posts.Content: Does anyone out there have any experience with the one week radiation treatment, direct to tumor site - not whole breast rad for 4-7 weeks?  I am considering this option because I don't want to go through the 5 week rad tx which left terrible side effects that are forever lasting like breast lyphmedema.  This cancer is  in the other breast and not connected to the other cancer but is alike. Thanks for any info...   Jill
Posts.Title: One week radiation tx

Posts.Content: On 10/15/2008 tomslady wrote:   On 10/15/2008 JillW wrote: Does anyone out there have any experience with the one week radiation treatment, direct to tumor site - not whole breast rad for 4-7 weeks?  I am considering this option because I don't want to go through the 5 week rad tx which left terrible side effects that are forever lasting like breast lyphmedema.  This cancer is  in the other breast and not connected to the other cancer but is alike. Thanks for any info...   Jill Kristine sorry about the confusion.  Had cancer in left breast 2 yr ago, tumor removed & 4 weeks rad tx.  YOU WERE VERY LUCKY!  I now have a new cancer in the opposite breast and will have the tumor removed and possibly the nipple.  The 5 day tx is called Mamosite and can be found on the internet with all the info.  There are criteria that you need to meet like the margins have to be clear, they insert a balloon into the space the tumor was with seeds in it and you are radiated twice a day for 5 days.  They have been doing it for about 5 years I think. It is still experimental but the results have been very good.  Jill I guess I don't understand what you are telling us. You have had cancer removed from one breast and it is also in the other one and they want to do 5 radiation tx on the breast that still has the cancer. Why have you not had the cancer removed and no I have not heard of the 5 day tx. I just finished 3 weeks ago. I have 33 tx, 28 regular and 5 boost and the only thing I had was the last 3 days very tired. I worked all the way through and did not have any pain or skin issues. My scars on the breast look awsome, the tx make them smaller and flat and very light. I am amazed at truely painless is was. I was expecting the worst, so the few days of being tired was nooooo big deal at all.   Kristine
Posts.Title: One week radiation tx
